title: Vince Cable: Boris Johnson could declare national emergency to force no-deal Brexit
text:
Former Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable speaks at the Liberal Democrat Party Conference on September 15, 2019 in Bournemouth, England | Finnbarr Webster/Getty Images Vince Cable: Boris Johnson could declare national emergency to force no-deal Brexit UK government could temporarily suspend rule of law and take Britain out of the EU without a deal, says former Liberal Democrat leader.

LONDON — A senior U.K. opposition MP voiced concern that Prime Minister Boris Johnson could declare a state of national emergency in order to bypass legislation aimed at preventing a no-deal Brexit on October 31.

“My worry at the moment is that the government might try to fabricate an emergency situation as a pretext for pushing through changes around a no-deal Brexit that they otherwise cannot secure in parliament,” Vince Cable, former business secretary and leader of the Liberal Democrats, told POLITICO Thursday. “There is a risk that we get an agent provocateur ... which the government uses as a pretext to obtaining emergency powers.”

The Benn Act compels the prime minister to ask Brussels for an extension of the Article 50 period if no Brexit deal has been agreed by October 19. Johnson has both said he will not request an extension and that he will not break the U.K. law.

Under the Civil Contingencies Act 2004, U.K. ministers can suspend the rule of law for 30 days after declaring a state of emergency in the country. The act also provides the government with wide-ranging powers to put in place regulations to deal with emergencies that threaten “serious damage to human welfare,” or that could damage the security of the country.

In January, Mark Sedwill, the U.K.’s cabinet secretary and head of the civil service, had said the government has no expectation it will need to use these powers in the event of a no-deal Brexit.

But Cable said Downing Street has recently talked up the prospects of riots and civil unrest if MPs prevent the U.K. from exiting the EU on October 31.

He added it would be relatively easy for the government to substantiate that there is an emergency situation. Ministers would only need to prove that an event or situation could cause loss of human life or injury, or disruption to communication networks, transport systems, or the supply of money, food, water, energy or fuel.

Opposition MPs are meeting regularly to find ways of ensuring Johnson does not take Britain out of the EU without a deal, but according to Cable, in that scenario, MPs may struggle to successfully challenge the Johnson in time to avert a no-deal Brexit, with any legal challenge potentially reaching the Supreme Court.

“It would be a travesty if that happened because Britain is a peaceful, law-abiding country,” Cable said.

A spokesperson for Downing Street said: “The PM has said that what we want to do is get a deal, and get Brexit done on October 31 without any further pointless delay. Yesterday, we put forward a fair and reasonable compromise, that we hope should provide the basis for rapid negotiations towards a solution.

“There is no purpose in discussing hypothetical scenarios around the Benn Act. It is without question that the Prime Minister will comply with the law.”
description: UK government could temporarily suspend rule of law and take Britain out of the EU without a deal, says former Liberal Democrat leader.
